author: reshm
title: Transaction monitoring as a service
description: DApps having to poll the blockchain to check status of transactions is not time efficient and involves duplicated work.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a very quality project from the core idea to the presentation of the content, the proposer has recognized the problem and described the solution for this proposal extremely well. The main purpose of this project is to develop a service that offers transaction monitoring which dApps can subscribe for, to get call backs about on-chain transactions status. The author has done a great job in demonstrating the necessity and effectiveness of the service they are going to develop. Starting from the analysis of two popular methods used by dApps to update transaction status, the disadvantages of these two methods are low efficiency, high cost, and long time. The proposer then describes his/her method including core features, how it works, and emphasizes the advantages of the solution as cost optimization, better scalability, time-saving. Through this project, the proposer wishes to help dApps developers to save their effort of writing their code in both cost and time. The author also clearly outlines the success of the project, I fully believe that the proposer's solution can solve the problem that the challenge poses, in line with Challenge's key metrics of reducing barriers for developers build on Cardano and create a great experience for developers.
f6_assessments.q1: The discription in this section is very detailed, the proposer has done very well to prepare for the successful implementation of this project. They develop a long-term plan for the development of the project, divided into several sub-phases, each of which clearly spells out what will happen and the goals to be achieved. The budget is allocated based on the necessary resources (human, infrastructure) for the development of the project. We can completely know the number of core members in the project, their roles, and working time. Basically, budget allocation is reasonable, the direction of cash flow into resources is consistent with the project development plan. If possible, I encourage proposers to allocate budgets at an hourly rate, meaning the number of hours worked by members, which makes it easy for the community to compare against other projects. There is no doubt about their staff, the core members of the project all have deep experience in the project field they are pursuing, their team also has active activities and significant contributions in the Cardano ecosystem. The team has enough experience and skills to realize this project and the proponent also provides us with Linkedin profiles, records of previous projects done for verification.
f6_assessments.q2: In the previous parts, the proposer provided us with a GitHub link so that those interested in the project could keep an eye on what the project's activities were going on. The success indicators are also clearly outlined, they have built a roadmap to measure the success of the project including 3 phases, the goals to be achieved, and the actual KPIs. The goals are all well established at the right time intervals, this helps them to develop the project in the right direction and it is easy for the community to follow the development direction of the project.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer leads us to the solution to those issues, which is this project, by bringing out two common techniques and explaining why they are insufficient. The advantages of this solution may outweigh the advantages of two previous approaches. The variety of use cases is extensive. f6_assessments.q1: This roadmap is quite detailed and divided into little prints. The proposer additionally includes diagrammatic illustrations to aid comprehension. The roadmap can be modularized based on the proposer's preferences, but in general, the milestones are well planned and linked to one another. The feasibility possibility for a detailed plan like this will undoubtedly increase. The budget is determined and allocated based on team member, not hour. Members of the team have amassed a very diversified set of talents and experience across a wide variety of fields and from previous fund. Referrals on LinkedIn, Twitter were provided, so experience can be validated from that standpoint. f6_assessments.q2: The proposer did an excellent job defying the target in one month, three months, six months, and twelve months. By offering a particular figure, the proposer gives the community a better chance to audit the progress and see where it is going. I believe the outcome is relevant to the challenge setting. Furthermore, how the team measured the project was clearly and easily shown. I am confident in the project's success because of its foresight.

If ready-made APIs are available to monitor transactions as a service it will definitely help a large number of developers. the availability of such services will further decrease the development time required for small-scale Dapp.  based on this consideration it is felt that the proposal is in alignment with the challenge.

f6_assessments.q2: The proposal aims to complete the project before September 2022 and then assist the users in exploiting the service. The project aims to provide a service; therefore, its success can be easily measured and highly auditable.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal offers a functionality that may iniatially seem appealing, especially to small Dapps that want to launch with minimal infrastructure (not even a single full node). However, it is very important, in my opinion, that the Cardano community steers clear to any kind of centralized service. This proposal team state one of their goals is 'adoption as the de facto solution for transaction monitoring', but make no attempt to decentralize the service, and even relies on other centralized services.  It is up to the voters, and ultimately developers and users to decide what kind of service they want to use, but I cannot agree this has a positive effect on the Cardano ecosystem, and therefore, that is aligned with the challenge brief.
Additionally, there was already another proposal funded in Fund6 (now available as tangocrypto) that provides transaction webhooks.
f6_assessments.q1: A detailed and credible plan of development is presented, with a realistic timetable, that the proposed teams should meet with no issues. If anything, I'd say the plan is conservative, and the project could probably be completed in less time, or with less resources.
f6_assessments.q2: Project tracking is linked to the proposed plan, which is to be expected, but no details are offered on how will it be shared, as development milestones do not provide in this case any public facing results until the project is quite advanced (around sprint 6 on testnet deployment). The best solution would be to open the project tracking board (e.g. github, jira..).
